item.paragraph:
Formatting of this note might be different from the original.
Please read all discharge instructions. Take medications as prescribed. Please follow-up for reevaluation of your symptoms. Return to the emergency department immediately for any concerning symptoms such as worsening pain, increased swelling, numbness, tingling, or weakness.

item.caption: ED Attending TestPhysician, MD - 11/17/2021 11:48 AM MST
item.paragraph:
Formatting of this note is different from the original.
Final diagnoses:
Acromioclavicular (AC) joint injury, left, initial encounter
Snowboarding accident, initial encounter
New Prescriptions
No medications on file
Follow Up Plan: Test Orthopedics - Colorado
11650 West 2nd Pl
Lakeville Colorado 80228
555-321-1234
FOLLOW UP:, Follow up with your home orthopedist, within 1 week
Medications - No data to display
There are no discharge medications for this patient.
Chief Complaint: Shoulder Pain
HPI: This 27 y.o. male presents to the Kno2 Medical Center via Kno2 ski patrol due to left shoulder pain that occurred just prior to arrival when the patient was snowboarding at Kno2 ski resort and caught an edge, falling onto the left side of the head and the left shoulder. He did not lose consciousness. He complains of 4 out of 10 pain to the left shoulder. He denies any numbness, tingling, or weakness. He denies any other injury.
ROS:
General: No generalized weakness.
CV: Denies chest pain.
Respiratory: Denies cough or shortness of breath.
GI: Denies nausea or abdominal pain.
Musculoskeletal: See history of the present illness. Denies neck pain. Denies back pain.
Skin: Denies lacerations. Denies abrasions.
Neuro: Denies headache. Denies numbness or tingling. Denies localized weakness.
Allergies:No Known Allergies

None

Triage Vital Signs:
BP: 153/86
Temp: 36 °C (96.8 °F)
Pulse: 80
Resp: 18
SpO2: 93 %
Physical Examination: Patient is well nourished, well developed, alert, oriented and displaying normal affect. GCS is 15. Cervical spine is nontender to palpation with good range of motion without posterior neck pain. Thoracic and lumbar spine is nontender to palpation. Lungs are clear. Abdomen is soft and nontender. Examination of the AC joint reveals a deformity compatible with a grade 3 subluxation. Patient is tender directly over the AC joint area. Distal neurovascular examination of the injured him upper extremity is intact.
Medical Decision Making:
Differential diagnoses considered includes clavicle fracture, AC joint disruption, sternal clavicular dislocation, humeral head fracture, and rotator cuff injury. Radiology Impression:
I ordered the study and personally reviewed the images on the PACS system.
Results for orders placed or performed during the hospital encounter of 11/17/21
XR Acromioclavicular Joint Left without Weight
Narrative
HISTORY:
Left shoulder pain
COMPARISON:
None.
FINDINGS:
Single anterior view of the acromioclavicular joint obtained.
There is no fracture. There is no glenohumeral dislocation. Widening of the AC joint noted, consistent with grade 2 acromioclavicular separation. No lytic or sclerotic bone lesions identified.
Impression
Acromioclavicular separation as discussed above.
Thank you for this referral. This examination was interpreted by a Imaging Associates radiologist. Providers with questions may reach a radiologist directly at 555-123-5678.
WS: CTestPhysician-HP
DICTATED BY: TestPhysician Date: 11/17/2021 12:15 MT
TRANSCRIBED DATE: 11/17/2021 12:15 MT
ED Course: Patient presents with left shoulder pain and deformity focused around the acromioclavicular joint. X-rays show widening of the acromioclavicular joint. It was read as a grade 2, however I am concerned it may be wider than that. I did discuss this with the patient. He was placed in a sling and swath. He declined pain medication or an injection of local anesthesia in the clinic. I did offer him a prescription for pain medication, which he declined. I did recommend that he use ice, acetaminophen, and ibuprofen for symptom management. I recommended that he follow-up with orthopedic surgery in approximately 1 week for further evaluation and treatment. The patient is stable for discharge to home.
A sling is placed on the patient by the tech for comfort and stabilization.
Pain management is addressed.
ED Attending TestPhysician, MD
11/17/21 1236
Electronically signed by ED Attending TestPhysician, MD at 11/17/2021 12:36 PM MST
